column16: Did the decision state the landlord was represented?
column17: Did the tenant propose a payment plan?
column18: If the tenant did propose a payment plan, did the member accept the proposed payment plan?
column19: Did the decision state that the tenant had children living with them?
column20: Was the tenant employed at the time of the hearing?
column21: Did the decision state the tenant was represented?
column22: If the tenant had a history of arrears, did the decision mention a history of the tenant making payments on those arrears (separate from any payments made in response to the present eviction notice/hearing)?
column23: If the tenant was not employed, did the decision state the tenant was receiving any form of government assistance (e.g. OW, childcare benefits, ODSP, OSAP)?
column24: If the tenant was employed, did the decision state any doubts about the stability of employment e.g. lack of guaranteed hours, contract work, etc.?
column25: Did the member find the tenant had sufficient income to pay rent?

Date:	2018-06-04
File number:	
TNL-04435-18

Citation:	TNL-04435-18 (Re), 2018 CanLII 113807 (ON LTB), <https://canlii.ca/t/hwbjl>, retrieved on 2023-05-23
Content:


            Order
under Sections 69 and 77
 
Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
 
File Number: TNL-04435-18
TNL-03907-18



 


 


 



 
VK
and EK (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and
evict (’AM’) and (‘AV’) (together, the 'Tenants') because the Tenants did not
pay the rent that the Tenants owe (‘L1 application’).
 
The
Landlords also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the
Tenants because they, another occupant of the rental unit or someone they
permitted in the residential complex have substantially interfered with the
reasonable enjoyment or lawful right, privilege or interest of the Landlords or
another tenant (‘L2 application’).
 
The
Landlords also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the
Tenants because the Tenants entered into an agreement to terminate the tenancy (‘L3
application’).
 
This
combined application was heard in Newmarket on May 30, 2018.
 
The Landlords and the Tenant, (‘AM’), assisted by duty counsel, GO,
attended the hearing.
 
 
Preliminary Issue – adjournment request denied 
 
1.   
The Tenant, AM, initially attended on his own and requested an
adjournment because the second named Tenant was at work and therefore was not
present.
 
2.   
No notice had been given to the Board or to the Landlords that an
adjournment would be requested, and no reason was given why AV could not
arrange to be present or why AM could not speak for and represent AV, who is
his girlfriend.
 
3.   
The conduct alleged in the application is serious and ongoing. 
The Tenant, AV did not act reasonably in not attending the hearing and in not
sending someone to represent her, and it was unfair to the Landlord to adjourn
the hearing.  I declined the request for an adjournment.
 
4.   
The hearing was held down until later in the day at which time the
Tenant, AM attended with the assistance of duty counsel.
Determinations:
 
L1 application
 
5.      The
Tenants do not dispute that they have not paid the total rent they were
required to pay for the period from February 15, 2018 to June 14, 2018. 
Because of the arrears, the Landlords served a Notice of Termination effective
April 7, 2018.
 
6.      The
Landlords collected a rent deposit of $1,200.00 from the Tenants and this
deposit is still being held by the Landlords.
 
7.      Interest
on the rent deposit is owing to the Tenants for the period from November 13,
2017 to April 7, 2018.
L2
application
8.      The
Tenants do not dispute the allegations made by the Landlords.  The uncontested
testimony of the Landlords establishes that the Tenants have engaged in loud
shouting and throwing of items and arguing late at night, and that this disruptive
conduct has substantially interfered with the Landlords' and the other tenants'
reasonable enjoyment of the residential complex.  The Tenants did not correct
the problem within the time period set out in the Notice of Termination.
L3
application
9.      The
alleged agreement relied upon by the Landlords is signed by the Tenant, AM
only.  It is not signed by the second named Tenant and there is no evidence
that it was signed on her behalf or with her authority.  The agreement is not
enforceable against the Tenant, AV.
Section
83
10.   The
Tenants do not oppose the termination of the tenancy, but ask that eviction be
postponed until June 30, 2018.  They agree that the postponement should be
conditional upon (a) their payment of $1,000.00 toward the arrears on or before
Friday, June 8, 2018; and no further substantial interference with the
reasonable enjoyment of other tenants taking place, and that, in the event of a
breach of either of those conditions, the Landlord should be entitled to
immediately apply to the Board pursuant to section 78 of the Residential
Tenancies Act, 2006 (the 'Act') without notice to the Tenants for immediate
termination of the tenancy.  
11.   The
Landlords oppose any delay in the eviction because of the serious and
persistent pattern of disruptive conduct by the Tenants.
12.   The
delay requested by the Tenants is only 15 days beyond the date on which the
eviction would take place under the Board’s standard 11 day eviction order, and
will allow the Tenants some additional time to find new accommodation and move
out. I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with
subsection 83(2) of the Act, and find that it would not be unfair to postpone
the eviction until June 30, 2018 pursuant to subsection 83(1)(b) of the Act, subject
to the conditions set out in this order pursuant to subsection 83(1)(a) and
204(1) of the Act.  
It is ordered that:
 
1.      The
tenancy may continue until June 30, 2018 on the condition that the Tenants:
 
(a)  pay to
the Landlords $1,000.00 on or before June 8, 2018; and 
 
(b)  do not
engage in any conduct that substantially interferes with the reasonable
enjoyment of the residential complex by the Landlords or by other tenants.
 
2.      If
the Tenants fail to comply with either of the conditions set out in paragraph 1
above, the Landlords may, without further notice to the Tenants, apply within
30 days to the Board pursuant to section 78 of the Act for an order
terminating the tenancy and evicting the Tenants.
3.      The
tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenants is terminated.  The Tenants
must move out of the rental unit on or before June 30, 2018.
4.      The
Tenants shall pay to the Landlords $2,826.25*, which represents the amount of
rent owing and compensation up to June 4, 2018, less the rent deposit and
interest the Landlords owe on the rent deposit.
5.      The
Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $39.45 per day for compensation for the
use of the unit starting June 5, 2018 to the date they move out of the unit.
6.      The
Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the
application.
7.      If
the Tenants do not pay the Landlords the full amount owing* on or before June
15, 2018, the Tenants will start to owe interest.  This will be simple interest
calculated from June 16, 2018 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
8.      If
the unit is not vacated on or before June 30, 2018, then starting July 1, 2018,
the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff)
so that the eviction may be enforced.
9.      Upon
receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to
give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlords, on or after July 1, 2018.
 
June 4, 2018                                                                       _______________________
Date Issued                                                                       Neil
Kaufman
                                                                                                                           Member,
Landlord and Tenant Board
Toronto North-RO
47 Sheppard Avenue East, Suite 700, 7th Floor
Toronto ON M2N5X5
 
If you have any questions about this order, call 416-645-8080 or
toll free at 1-888-332-3234.
 
In accordance with section 81 of the Act, the part of this order
relating to the eviction expires on January 1, 2019 if the order has not been
filed on or before this date with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) that
has territorial jurisdiction where the rental unit is located.
 
*           Refer to section A on the attached Summary of
Calculations.




Schedule 1
SUMMARY OF CALCULATIONS
 
File Number: TNL-04435-18
 
A.        Amount the Tenants must pay if the tenancy is
terminated:
 



Reasons for amount owing


Period


Amount



 



 Arrears: (up to the termination date in
  the Notice of Termination)


February 15, 2018 to April 7, 2018


$1,746.85



 
 



Plus compensation: (from the day after the
  termination date in the Notice to the date of the order)


April 8, 2018 to June 4, 2018


$2,288.10



 



Less the rent deposit:


 


-$1,200.00



 



Less the interest owing on the rent deposit:


November 13, 2017 to April 7, 2018


-$8.70



 
 



Amount owing to the Landlords on the order date:(total of previous boxes)


$2,826.25



 
 



Additional costs the Tenants must pay to the Landlords:


$190.00



 
 



Plus daily compensation owing for each day of occupation
  starting June 5, 2018:


$39.45 (per
  day)



 
 



Total the Tenants must pay the Landlords if the tenancy is
  terminated:


$3,016.25, + $39.45 per day starting June 5, 2018

The tenancy may continue until June 30, 2018 on the condition that the Tenants:  (a) pay to the Landlords $1,000.00 on or before June 8, 2018; and  (b) do not engage in any conduct that substantially interferes with the reasonable enjoyment of the residential complex by the Landlords or by other tenants.  2. If the Tenants fail to comply with either of the conditions set out in paragraph 1 above, the Landlords may, without further notice to the Tenants, apply within 30 days to the Board pursuant to section 78 of the Act for an order terminating the tenancy and evicting the Tenants. 3. The tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenants is terminated. The Tenants must move out of the rental unit on or before June 30, 2018. 4. The Tenants shall pay to the Landlords $2,826.25*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation up to June 4, 2018, less the rent deposit and interest the Landlords owe on the rent deposit. 5. The Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $39.45 per day for compensation for the use of the unit starting June 5, 2018 to the date they move out of the unit. 6. The Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the application. 7. If the Tenants do not pay the Landlords the full amount owing* on or before June 15, 2018, the Tenants will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from June 16, 2018 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding. 8. If the unit is not vacated on or before June 30, 2018, then starting July 1, 2018, the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced. 9. Content:


Order under Section 21.2 of the 
Statutory Powers Procedure Act 
and the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006
 
File Number: TSL-07666-19-RV
 










 
 

Review Order
 
M
D and B K (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and
evict O G and K D (the 'Tenants') because the Tenants did not pay the rent that
the Tenants owe. (L1 Application)
 
The
Landlords also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the
Tenants because the Landlords require possession of the rental unit for the
purpose of residential occupation; and because the Tenants have been
persistently late in paying their rent. The Landlords also claimed compensation
for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date. (L2
Application)
 
This
L1/L2 Application was resolved by order TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019.
 
On September 3, 2019, the Tenants requested a review of the order
and that the order be stayed until the request to review the order is resolved.

 
On September 4, 2019, interim order TSL-07666-19-IN was issued,
staying the order issued on August 30, 2019.
 
The request was heard in Toronto on November 1, 2019.
 
The Landlords; the Landlords’ legal representative, M P; and the
Tenants attended the hearing.
 
 
 
 
Determinations:
 
Request
to review granted
1.      At
the hearing, the Landlords consented to the Tenants’ request to review. I
proceeded to hear the application de novo. 
Merits
hearing 
L1
Application: Tenants owe the Landlords $3,854.79
2.      At
the hearing, the Tenants did not dispute the amount the Landlords claim they
owe. They acknowledge that they owe the Landlords approximately two months’
rent. One month represents the Tenants’ failure to pay rent in May 2019 because
they expected the Landlords to apply their last month’s rent deposit to that
month, improperly so. The other month represents the rent for November 2019,
which was due on the day of the review hearing but had not been paid as of the
hearing.  
3.      Based
on the evidence before me, I am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that as
of the review hearing, the Tenants owed the Landlords $3,854.79, including
arrears of rent to November 30, 2019 and the application filing fee. If the
Tenants have since made any payments to the Landlords, including for November’s
rent, those amounts should be deducted from the amount owing in this order.
L2
Application: Persistent late payments and Landlords’ own use
4.      The
parties do not dispute that the Tenants paid their rent late for eight of the
13 months between May 2018 and May 2019 as claimed in the N8 Notice of
Termination. Therefore, I am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the
Tenants have persistently paid their rent late.
5.      I
am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the Landlords genuinely intend
to occupy the rental unit for residential purposes for a period of at least one
year. 
6.      The
Landlords testified that they recently sold their home in Mississauga and they
intend to move into the rental unit so they can be closer to the hospital where
the female Landlord has regular appointments and treatments and so they can
downsize in preparation for the male Landlord’s retirement. 
7.      The
Tenants testified that they do not believe that the Landlords genuinely intend
to move into the rental unit because the Landlords have repeatedly threatened
to evict the Tenants in connection with various behaviour, including after the
Landlords discovered that the Tenants were growing marijuana plants in the
rental unit. The Landlords denied that they served the N12 Notice of
Termination for any ulterior motive, including in response to the Tenants’
marijuana plants. The only evidence the Tenants produced to corroborate their
position is a text message from the male Landlord from March 30, 2019, stating
that if the Tenants denied the Landlords’ access to the rental unit to repair a
faucet there would be an eviction notice. However, I do not find that this is
sufficient evidence of an ulterior motive, especially compared to the evidence
the Landlords submitted in support of their position that they are intending to
move into the unit. 
8.      The
Landlords submitted the agreement of purchase and sale for their previous home.
The Landlords also submitted booking confirmations for Airbnb units that they
have been living in since the sale of their home closed. Together this evidence
supports the Landlords’ testimony that they were intending to move into the
rental unit after they sold their previous home, they are still waiting for
this to happen and they are prepared to move into the rental unit as soon as it
becomes vacant. The Landlords also submitted a letter from the female
Landlord’s doctor confirming that the female Landlord receives weekly
treatments at the Princess Margaret Hospital, which is closer to the rental
unit than it was to the Landlords’ previous home. 
9.      The
parties do not dispute that the Landlords paid the one month’s compensation
required by sections 48.1 and 55.1 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the
“Act”) by waiving the Tenants’ rent for April 2019.
Section
83 considerations 
10.   I
have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with
subsection 83(2) of the Act, and find that it would be unfair to grant relief
from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act.
11.   The
Tenants have had considerable time to find another place to live since they
received the notices of termination months ago. The Tenants’ have a combined
household income of over $5,000.00, which is not insignificant. Although the
Tenants testified that they have had a difficult time finding another affordable
place to move into, they did not bring proof of the results of their housing
search in support of this claim. 
12.   The
Tenants raised a maintenance issue in the rental unit – a portion of the
ceiling which is discoloured. The Tenants did not submit evidence to establish
that this is a serious breach of the Landlords’ responsibilities under the Act
to merit mandatory refusal of eviction under subsection 83(3) of the Act. On
the other hand, the Landlords submitted an inspection report for the unit that
was prepared in May 2019, which indicates that the discolouration is a stain
that can be removed with a foot powder spray.
13.   Ultimately,
I find there is no reason to delay eviction any further. 
14.   Since
the arrears have changed since the original order was issued, I find it
appropriate to replace that order with an updated calculation of the amount
owing. 
It is ordered that:
 
1.      The
request to review order TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019 is granted. 
2.      Order
TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019 is replaced with the following terms. 
3.      The
tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenants is terminated, as of December 1,
2019. The Tenants must move out of the rental unit on or before December 1,
2019.
4.      The
Tenants shall pay to the Landlords $1,238.53*, which represents the amount of
rent owing and compensation up to November 20, 2019, less the rent deposit and
interest the Landlords owe on the rent deposit.
5.      The
Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $60.24 per day for compensation for the
use of the unit starting November 21, 2019 to the date the Tenants move out of
the unit.
6.      The
Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the
application.
7.      If
the Tenants do not pay the Landlords the full amount owing* on or before
December 1, 2019, the Tenants will start to owe interest.  This will be simple
interest calculated from December 2, 2019 at 3.00% annually on the balance
outstanding.
8.      If
the unit is not vacated on or before December 1, 2019, then starting December
2, 2019, the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office
(Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
9.      Upon
receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to
give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlords on or after December 2,
2019.
 
 
November 20, 2019                                                        _______________________
Date Issued                                                                      Anna
Solomon
                                                                                                                           Member,
Landlord and Tenant Board
 
Toronto South-RO
15 Grosvenor Street, 1st Floor
Toronto ON M7A 2G6
 
 
 
If you have any questions about this order, call 416-645-8080 or
toll free at 1-888-332-3234.
 
In accordance with section 81 of the Act, the part of this order
relating to the eviction expires on June 2, 2020 if the order has not been
filed on or before this date with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) that
has territorial jurisdiction where the rental unit is located.
 
*           Refer to the attached Summary of Calculations.

SUMMARY OF CALCULATIONS
 
File Number: TSL-07666-19
 
Amount the Tenants must pay the Landlords:
 



Reasons for amount owing


Period


Amount



 



 Arrears: (up to the termination date in
  the Notice of Termination)


June 1, 2019 to June 25, 2019


$1,506.08



 
 



Less the amount the Tenants paid to the Landlords


 


-$7,329.61



 



Plus compensation: (from the day after the
  termination date in the Notice to the date of the order)


June 26, 2019 to November 20, 2019


$8,915.52



 



Less the rent deposit:


 


-$1,800.00



 



Less the interest owing on the rent deposit:


November 1, 2017 to June 25, 2019


-$53.46



 
 



Amount owing to the Landlords on the order date:(total of previous boxes)


$1,238.53



 
 



Additional costs the Tenants must pay to the Landlords:


$190.00



 
 



Plus daily compensation owing for each day of occupation
  starting November 21, 2019:


$60.24 (per
  day)



 
 



Total the Tenants must pay the Landlords:


$1,428.53, + $60.24 per day starting November 21, 2019

The Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the application. 7.  If the Tenants do not pay the Landlords the full amount owing* on or before December 1, 2019, the Tenants will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from December 2, 2019 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding. 8.  If the unit is not vacated on or before December 1, 2019, then starting December 2, 2019, the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced. 9.  Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlords on or after December 2, 2019. November 20, 2019                   _______________________ Date Issued                        Anna Solomon Member, Landlord and Tenant Board Toronto South-RO 15 Grosvenor Street, 1st Floor Toronto ON M7A 2G6 If you have any questions about this order, call 416-645-8080 or toll free at 1-888-332-3234. In accordance with section 81 of the Act, the part of this order relating to the eviction expires on June 2, 2020 if the order has not been filed on or before this date with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) that has territorial jurisdiction where the rental unit is located. *    Refer to the attached Summary of Calculations. column5: Order under Section 21.2 of the Statutory Powers Procedure Act and the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006  File Number: TSL-07666-19-RV               Review Order  M D and B K (the 'Landlords') applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict O G and K D (the 'Tenants') because the Tenants did not pay the rent that the Tenants owe. (L1 Application)  The Landlords also applied for an order to terminate the tenancy and evict the Tenants because the Landlords require possession of the rental unit for the purpose of residential occupation; and because the Tenants have been persistently late in paying their rent. The Landlords also claimed compensation for each day the Tenants remained in the unit after the termination date. (L2 Application)  This L1/L2 Application was resolved by order TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019.  On September 3, 2019, the Tenants requested a review of the order and that the order be stayed until the request to review the order is resolved.   On September 4, 2019, interim order TSL-07666-19-IN was issued, staying the order issued on August 30, 2019.  The request was heard in Toronto on November 1, 2019.  The Landlords; the Landlords’ legal representative, M P; and the Tenants attended the hearing.     Determinations:  Request to review granted 1. At the hearing, the Landlords consented to the Tenants’ request to review. I proceeded to hear the application de novo. Merits hearing L1 Application: Tenants owe the Landlords $3,854.79 2. At the hearing, the Tenants did not dispute the amount the Landlords claim they owe. They acknowledge that they owe the Landlords approximately two months’ rent. One month represents the Tenants’ failure to pay rent in May 2019 because they expected the Landlords to apply their last month’s rent deposit to that month, improperly so. The other month represents the rent for November 2019, which was due on the day of the review hearing but had not been paid as of the hearing. 3. Based on the evidence before me, I am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that as of the review hearing, the Tenants owed the Landlords $3,854.79, including arrears of rent to November 30, 2019 and the application filing fee. If the Tenants have since made any payments to the Landlords, including for November’s rent, those amounts should be deducted from the amount owing in this order. L2 Application: Persistent late payments and Landlords’ own use 4. The parties do not dispute that the Tenants paid their rent late for eight of the 13 months between May 2018 and May 2019 as claimed in the N8 Notice of Termination. Therefore, I am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the Tenants have persistently paid their rent late. 5. I am satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the Landlords genuinely intend to occupy the rental unit for residential purposes for a period of at least one year. 6. The Landlords testified that they recently sold their home in Mississauga and they intend to move into the rental unit so they can be closer to the hospital where the female Landlord has regular appointments and treatments and so they can downsize in preparation for the male Landlord’s retirement. 7. The Tenants testified that they do not believe that the Landlords genuinely intend to move into the rental unit because the Landlords have repeatedly threatened to evict the Tenants in connection with various behaviour, including after the Landlords discovered that the Tenants were growing marijuana plants in the rental unit. The Landlords denied that they served the N12 Notice of Termination for any ulterior motive, including in response to the Tenants’ marijuana plants. The only evidence the Tenants produced to corroborate their position is a text message from the male Landlord from March 30, 2019, stating that if the Tenants denied the Landlords’ access to the rental unit to repair a faucet there would be an eviction notice. However, I do not find that this is sufficient evidence of an ulterior motive, especially compared to the evidence the Landlords submitted in support of their position that they are intending to move into the unit. 8. The Landlords submitted the agreement of purchase and sale for their previous home. The Landlords also submitted booking confirmations for Airbnb units that they have been living in since the sale of their home closed. Together this evidence supports the Landlords’ testimony that they were intending to move into the rental unit after they sold their previous home, they are still waiting for this to happen and they are prepared to move into the rental unit as soon as it becomes vacant. The Landlords also submitted a letter from the female Landlord’s doctor confirming that the female Landlord receives weekly treatments at the Princess Margaret Hospital, which is closer to the rental unit than it was to the Landlords’ previous home. 9. The parties do not dispute that the Landlords paid the one month’s compensation required by sections 48.1 and 55.1 of the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the “Act”) by waiving the Tenants’ rent for April 2019. Section 83 considerations 10. I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Act, and find that it would be unfair to grant relief from eviction pursuant to subsection 83(1) of the Act. 11. The Tenants have had considerable time to find another place to live since they received the notices of termination months ago. The Tenants’ have a combined household income of over $5,000.00, which is not insignificant. Although the Tenants testified that they have had a difficult time finding another affordable place to move into, they did not bring proof of the results of their housing search in support of this claim. 12. The Tenants raised a maintenance issue in the rental unit – a portion of the ceiling which is discoloured. The Tenants did not submit evidence to establish that this is a serious breach of the Landlords’ responsibilities under the Act to merit mandatory refusal of eviction under subsection 83(3) of the Act. On the other hand, the Landlords submitted an inspection report for the unit that was prepared in May 2019, which indicates that the discolouration is a stain that can be removed with a foot powder spray. 13. Ultimately, I find there is no reason to delay eviction any further. 14. Since the arrears have changed since the original order was issued, I find it appropriate to replace that order with an updated calculation of the amount owing. It is ordered that:  1. The request to review order TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019 is granted. 2. Order TSL-07666-19 issued on August 30, 2019 is replaced with the following terms. 3. The tenancy between the Landlords and the Tenants is terminated, as of December 1, 2019. The Tenants must move out of the rental unit on or before December 1, 2019. 4. The Tenants shall pay to the Landlords $1,238.53*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation up to November 20, 2019, less the rent deposit and interest the Landlords owe on the rent deposit. 5. The Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $60.24 per day for compensation for the use of the unit starting November 21, 2019 to the date the Tenants move out of the unit. 6. The Tenants shall also pay to the Landlords $190.00 for the cost of filing the application. 7. If the Tenants do not pay the Landlords the full amount owing* on or before December 1, 2019, the Tenants will start to owe interest. This will be simple interest calculated from December 2, 2019 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding. 8. If the unit is not vacated on or before December 1, 2019, then starting December 2, 2019, the Landlords may file this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced. 9. Upon receipt of this order, the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of the unit to the Landlords on or after December 2, 2019.   November 20, 2019 Date Issued Anna Solomon Member, Landlord and Tenant Board  Toronto South-RO 15 Grosvenor Street, 1st Floor Toronto ON M7A 2G6    If you have any questions about this order, call 416-645-8080 or toll free at 1-888-332-3234. Content:


Order
under Sections 30, 31 and 69
Residential
Tenancies Act, 2006
 
File
Numbers: SWL-13901-18
SWT-14627-18
 











 

Ontario Ltd. (the 'Landlord') applied for
an order to terminate the tenancy and evict KM (the 'Tenant') because the
Tenant did not pay the rent that the Tenant owes (the ‘L1 Application’).
 
The Tenant applied for an order determining
that the Landlord, the Landlord’s superintendent or
the Landlord’s agent withheld or deliberately interfered with the reasonable
supply of a vital service, care service, or food that the Landlord is obligated
to supply under the tenancy agreement (the ‘T2 Application’).
 
The Tenant also applied
for an order determining that the Landlord failed to meet the Landlord’s
maintenance obligations under the Residential Tenancies Act, 2006 (the
'Act') or failed to comply with health, safety, housing or maintenance
standards (the ‘T6 Application’). 
 
These applications were heard in [CITY] on
May 23, 2018.  The Landlord’s Agent, AA, the Tenant,
the Tenant’s Agent, GL, and the witness, BB, attended the hearing.
 
Preliminary Issues:
 
1.     The Tenant’s applications are amended to remove
A.A. as a party.
2.     The submitted tenancy agreement indicates that
the Landlord is a second mortgagee.  The first mortgagee, P.B., was not served
with Notice of the Hearing.  However, as A.A. advised that her corporation had
purchased the entirety of P.B.’s interest in the rental unit, I find no
prejudice to P.B. in proceeding with the hearing in his absence.  
Determinations and
Reasons:
The L1 Application
 
3.     The Tenant has not paid the total rent she was
required to pay for the period from February 1, 2018 to May 31, 2018.  Because
of the arrears, the Landlord served a Notice of Termination effective February
17, 2018.
4.     The Tenant is in possession of the rental unit. 
5.     The monthly rent is $1,050.00.
6.     The Landlord collected a rent deposit of
$1,050.00 from the Tenant and this deposit is still being held by the Landlord.
7.     Interest on the rent deposit is owing to the
Tenant for the period from July 22, 2017 to February 17, 2018.
8.     The parties agree that the amount outstanding to
May 31, 2018, inclusive of rent arrears ($4,200.00) and costs ($175.00), is
$4,375.00.  At the hearing, the Tenant agreed that she was four months in
arrears.  While she acknowledged that she wilfully withheld the rent in
retaliation for the outstanding maintenance issues, she also testified that
P.B. had attended at the rental unit and instructed her to pay the rent only to
him, rather than A.A. in response to a financial conflict between the two
mortgagees.  It is unclear if P.B.’s interference was a substantial factor in
the Tenant’s failure to pay the arrears as she did not pay him any portion of
the outstanding balance either.
9.     The Tenant supports three children on a rather
limited income and has so far been unable to find alternate housing in her
price range.  She requested that the eviction be postponed until the end of
June, 2018 to allow her children to complete their school year.  On the balance
of probabilities, I find that the Tenant will reasonably require additional
time to either void the order for eviction or secure new accommodations.
10.  I have considered all of the disclosed circumstances in
accordance with subsection 83(2) of the Act and find that it would not be
unfair to postpone the eviction until June 30, 2018, pursuant to subsection
83(1)(b) of the Act.
The T2 Application 
11.  According to the Tenant’s description of this issue in the
T2 Application and the evidence submitted at the hearing, the problem related
to a maintenance issue with the hot water heater rather than a situation in
which the Landlord or its agent withheld hot water from the Tenant or wilfully
interfered with its supply.
12.  As a result, I find that the Tenant should have included
this issue under the T6 Application rather than under the present T2
Application.  As the Act provides different remedies with regard to a
maintenance application compared to a T2 Application, the forms are not
interchangeable.
13.  Since the Landlord received notice that the Tenant intended
to raise this issue at the hearing, the matter of the hot water heater has been
addressed below under the proper T6 Application.
14.  Therefore, I do not find that the Landlord, the Landlord's
superintendent or the Landlord's agent withheld
a reasonable supply of a vital service, care service, or food that the Landlord
was obligated to supply under the tenancy agreement or deliberately interfered
with the reasonable supply of vital service, care service, or food.
The T6 Application – Water Leaks and the Kitchen Sink 
15.  The Tenant testified that she discovered that the kitchen
sink was leaking when she moved into the rental unit on July 21, 2017.  The
sink is located on a kitchen island with cabinets.  She notified the Landlord
of these issues on August 20, 2017 and around the same time, she also
discovered a maggot infestation that appeared to originate from under the
kitchen island.  On or about September 14, 2017, A.A.’s husband, O.A., attended
at the rental unit to investigate and conduct repairs.  She stated that he
removed the sink and cupboards, but promised to return the next day to complete
the work.  However, this did not occur.  Removal of the sink did not resolve
the underlying leak issue.
16.  At the hearing, she submitted photographs of the flooring
that had been under the moved kitchen island, showing a considerable amount of
food and other debris accumulated in this area.  Other images show several
maggots moving along what appears to be a baseboard or some other surface in
the rental unit.  She recalled that these photographs were taken at some point
in September, 2017.  She testified that in October, 2017, she discovered the
remains of a one kilogram bag of dog food under the baseboards under the
island.  This and other garbage wedged into the flooring apparently provided a
food source for the maggots. 
17.  She testified that O.A. did not return for five months and
the issue was only resolved when she replaced the cabinetry at her own expense.
 She submitted a receipt from B.B., her own contractor.  This document
indicated that he installed kitchen cabinets, a new countertop, sink and faucet
and completed all associated electrical plumbing and electrical work.  He also
installed a new dishwasher.  The total that B.B. charged for this work was
$600.00.  The receipt indicated that the Tenant had paid $125.00 of this amount
as of February 22, 2018, leaving a balance of $475.00 outstanding.  The Tenant
testified that she ultimately paid the full balance as A.A. refused to pay on
the grounds that she had not authorized the work.
18.  B.B. has known the Tenant for approximately twenty years. 
He has approximately twelve years’ experience in carpentry and related trades. 
He testified that A.A. sent him to pick up a new kitchen cabinet at Habitat for
Humanity (‘Habitat’) for the rental unit at some point in February, 2018 and advised
him that she had a credit with that agency.  When he attended at Habitat, he
discovered that no such credit was on file.  Habitat also had no cabinet set
aside for the Landlord as she had claimed.  He testified that despite an
agreement with A.A., A.A. only paid $125.00 of his $600.00 invoice for the work
completed in the rental unit; he confirmed that the Tenant paid the balance. 
He ultimately obtained the cabinets for the rental unit at Habitat, but
emphasized that these were not owned or set aside by the Landlord.
19.  B.B. also confirmed that the state of the Tenant’s kitchen
was “deplorable” and that she was using cutlery stored in boxes for meals as
there was no usable kitchen in the residence.
20.  The Tenant testified that she was understandably anxious
over the presence of maggots in the rental unit. 
21.  While she waited on repairs to her kitchen and now removed
sink, the Tenant was compelled to wash her dishes in the bathroom sink and tub,
as confirmed by photographs submitted at the hearing.  She testified that the
kitchen island and leak issues were eventually resolved in early January, 2018.
22.  A.A. did not dispute the Tenant’s evidence of the leak or
the ensuing maggots in the kitchen, but emphasized that she opened up the part
of the floor where they were discovered and waited one day to confirm that the
problem had been resolved.  I agree with A.A. that there was no logic in replacing
the cabinetry until the maggots had been eradicated.  However, on the evidence,
she appears to have taken no further steps in September, 2017 to confirm that
the problem was fully resolved when the Tenant did not advise her whether or
not there were still maggots in the kitchen.
23.  With respect to a serious health issue such as vermin in
the rental unit, I find that it was incumbent on the Landlord to take proactive
measures to confirm that these pests have been fully exterminated.
24.  For this reason, I find that the Landlord should have
entered the rental unit to resolve this issue as soon as possible.  While
A.A.’s consideration of the Tenant’s privacy while her mother was hospitalized
is laudable, the parties agreed that the Tenant was absent from the rental unit
for much of October, 2017.  During that period, the Landlord could have easily
completed the necessary repairs to the kitchen island in the Tenant’s absence
with minimal disruption to her enjoyment of the residence.
25.  As a result, I do not find that the Landlord resolved this
issue in an appropriately timely manner and therefore breached its duties under subsection 20(1) of the Act
for providing and maintaining a residential complex, including the rental units
in it, in a good state of repair and fit for habitation and for complying with
health, safety, housing and maintenance standards. 
26.  As I find that the Landlord’s breach caused substantial
disruption to the Tenant’s ability to normally reside in the rental unit and
significantly impinged on her use and enjoyment of the residence, I find that
the Tenant is entitled to an abatement of rent structured as follows:
a.    Loss of use of the kitchen sink from August 20,
2017 to January 1, 2018 at 15% ($697.15);
b.    Loss of the kitchen island from September 14, 2017
to January 31, 2018 at 5% ($237.62);
c.    Maggot infestation in rental unit for one month
at 50% ($525.00).
27.  Since neither the Tenant nor B.B. were particularly
specific in their recollections of dates, I have selected the narrowest ranges
of dates provided in their evidence at the hearing as the most reliable
evidence.  This remedy is intended to include compensation for the stress
suffered by the Tenant as a result of the Landlord’s delay in restoring her
kitchen.
28.  While the Tenant also requested compensation for her out of
pocket expenses incurred to pay B.B. for his renovation work, the evidence
indicated that the Tenant was not authorized to replace the dishwasher in the
rental unit and did not lead evidence to suggest that this work related to a
maintenance breach properly brought to the Landlord’s attention, let alone
included as a cause of action in either application.  As B.B.’s invoice failed
to itemize the cost of the replacement cabinetry separate from the unauthorized
upgrades, it is not possible to order compensation for the eligible items
alone.  As a result, this compensation will not be ordered.
29.   Lastly, the Tenant requested an award of $500.00
in “non-pecuniary damages” based upon the stress she endured while the
Landlord’s delayed repairing the issues in the rental unit.  The Tenant most
likely seeks an award of general damages pursuant to paragraph (9) of
subsection 30(1) of the Act.  As I noted above, the ordered abatement is intended
to address the emotional consequences of the Landlord’s conduct.  
30.   As well, the threshold for imposing general
damages would require extremely egregious conduct on the part of the Landlord. 
The leading authority on this issue is the Ontario Divisional Court’s analysis
in Mejia v. Cagini.[1] 
In that case, an unquestionably toxic relationship between the parties
culminated in an assault upon the tenant by three friends of the landlord, in
the landlord’s presence.  The Ontario Rental Housing Tribunal found the
assault took place in the presence of the tenant’s family and that its purpose
was to put pressure upon the tenant to vacate the premises.  The tenant
was required to attend hospital for treatment.  The Tribunal did not find
that the landlord had himself committed the assault, but found that he did
nothing to stop it and that he was responsible for the actions of his
friends.  The Tribunal found that the landlord had thereby interfered with
the reasonable use and enjoyment of the apartment by the tenant and his family
and awarded general damages.
31.   In light of all of the
circumstances, I do not find that the Landlord’s conduct in the present case
rises to the level of seriousness that would warrant an order of general
damages apart from the ordered abatement. 
The Hot Water Heater
32.  The Tenant testified that whenever it rains, the basement
tends to flood.  She offered no other details on the amount of water in the
basement or its effect on her use of the space.  However, between August 28 and
August 29, 2017, the Windsor area received substantial rainfall, resulting in
flooding of many homes, including this rental unit.  The Tenant stated that she
“lost everything in the flood” and that her washer and dryer as well as the hot
water heater were immersed in over one foot of water.
33.  The Landlord did not replace the heater for four weeks.  In
the interim, the Tenant states that she was forced to wash her laundry
elsewhere, taking cabs about the city.  While she described this out of pocket
expense as “cabs were killer,” she did not explain why she was unable to use a
more economical method of public transit.  Although A.A. did not contest the
Tenant’s evidence that the hot water heater was not repaired for four weeks,
the Tenant did not offer any explanation why her laundry could not have been
washed with cold water as she did not suggest that the washing machine was
disabled by the flood.  Although she estimated the total cost of commuting
through Windsor to attend commercial laundries at $300.00, she was unable to substantiate
this estimate with any receipts or other documentation at the hearing.
34.  However, the Tenant acknowledged that she waited for two or
three days before notifying A.A. of the flood in her basement as she presumed
that A.A. must know that the house was affected.  This necessarily delayed
resolution of the issue and may have caused irreparable damage to the heater that
could have been prevented had the Tenant contacted A.A. more promptly.
35.  While the Tenant testified about high hydro bills and the
Landlord’s slow and allegedly inadequate cleaning of the basement, as these
issues were not mentioned in the applications, the Tenant denied the Landlord
reasonable notice that she intended to raise these issues at the hearing.  As a
result, these issues will form no part of the order to follow other than as
context for the deteriorating relationship between the parties.
36.  A.A. testified that as soon as she was notified of the
water in the basement, she attended at the rental unit.  She attempted to
contact a restoration company; however, as much of Windsor had been affected by
severe flooding, none were available in short order.
37.  However, when she and O.A. attended at the rental unit to
inspect the damage, the Tenant’s boyfriend told them not to worry about the
basement and that he would take care of it.  While the Tenant was reluctant to
allow A.A. to enter the rental unit or to assist her with cleaning the
basement, A.A. insisted on addressing the issue as soon as possible to avoid
further damage.  She testified that she was able to remove most of the Tenant’s
property from the affected area and cleaned approximately half of the basement. 

38.  In her own testimony, the Tenant expressed dissatisfaction
with the assistance offered by A.A. and her husband, more in relation to the
speed of their efforts.  As she put it, they “moved like turtles.”
39.  Despite numerous hisses and gasps of derision, the Tenant
did not substantively contest A.A.’s testimony that her boyfriend largely
commandeered the repairs to the basement, insisting on various supplies and
interfering with the efforts of the Landlord’s contractors to replace the
tank.  This version of events was confirmed by a letter from E.P., A.A.’s
regular contractor stating that when he initially attended at the rental unit
to complete the work, the Tenant’s boyfriend interfered with his efforts and
insisted that he complete the work himself.  To that end, the boyfriend gave
A.A. a lengthy list of materials that a later electrician deemed unnecessary
and serving only to waste time.
40.  Unlike the issues in the kitchen, the evidence with respect
to the delay in replacing the water heater includes a significant element of interference
by the Tenant and her boyfriend despite the Landlord’s concerted efforts to
resolve the issue.  As well, particular circumstances related to the widespread
flooding of basements throughout the city at the time hampered A.A.’s
reasonable access to remediation that could have been more readily available at
other times.
41.  Putting
aside the Tenant’s failure to request a remedy for the items allegedly damaged
in the basement by the flood itself, she also failed to demonstrate that the
Landlord could have reasonably anticipated this event.  In McQuestion v.
Schneider, the Ontario Court of Appeal held that liability for injuries or
damages could not be imposed on a landlord who had no knowledge or could not reasonably be expected to have knowledge of a
maintenance problem.[2] 
The Court held that then subsection 96(1) of the Landlord and Tenant Act
(now subsection 20(1) of the Act):
… does not impose an absolute liability upon a landlord for
any injuries or damages that may be caused by a latent defect, of which the
landlord has no knowledge, nor could reasonably be expected to have had such
knowledge. To alter the law so drastically as to impose strict liability on a
landlord, regardless of his knowledge or constructive knowledge, would require
much more precise language.[3]
42.  In
light of the all of evidence at the hearing, I find that the extreme flooding in
August, 2017 was not reasonably foreseeable.  While the Tenant testified that
the basement was subject to occasional wetness, on the evidence, the sheer
volume of water entering the rental unit in the last days of August, 2017 was
unexpected and unforeseeable.  There was also no evidence that the Tenant had
even notified the Landlord of the more minor moisture issues in the rental
unit.  As a result, I do not find that the Landlord failed to meet its
maintenance obligations under subsection 20(1) of the Act with respect to the
initial flooding.  As a result, the Landlord cannot be held liable for the
Tenant’s initial losses caused by the flood itself.  
43.  In Onyskiw v. CJM Property Management Ltd. the
Ontario Court of Appeal rejected a long-standing presumption that a landlord
may be deemed immediately in breach of subsection 20(1) of the Act once a
defect arises: 
58.  If the
legislature intended an automatic breach of the landlord’s duty to maintain and
repair as soon as a service was interrupted, there would be no need for the
Board to make a determination as to whether the landlord had breached its
obligation. The legislation would instead simply provide that where a service
has been interrupted the landlord is in breach of its duty to maintain and
repair and provide that the Board “may” award a remedy under s. 30(1) which
authorizes a range of remedies including an abatement of rent.
59.  The
tenants’ position that the landlord is automatically in breach of its statutory
obligation to maintain and repair even while something is being repaired also
offends the legal maxim lex non cogit ad
impossibilia: that the legislature does not intend compliance
where, for all practical purposes, it is impossible: see Côté, The Interpretation of Legislation in Canada, at p.
479.
60.  Applying
general principles of statutory interpretation, I would reject the tenants’
submission that, when the RTA is properly interpreted, a landlord is
automatically in breach of its obligation to repair and maintain under s. 20(1)
as soon as an interruption in service occurs.[4]
 
44.  The prior leading authority on this issue was the Supreme
Court of Canada’s decision in Pajelle Investments Ltd. v. Herbold.[5]  However, as the
Court in Onyskiw held, in light of the evolution in the law in the
decades since that case was decided, Pajelle also stands for the
principle that a contextual approach is necessary when considering whether the
landlord responded appropriately to a maintenance defect.  Such a reading is
appropriate having regard to the interpretive principle that legislation enacted
to regulate an activity that is ongoing over an extended period of time invites
a dynamic, as opposed to a fixed, interpretation.[6]
45.  This contextual approach is also consistent with the
Board’s Interpretation Guideline 5, which states as follows:
If a landlord
has done little maintenance for an extended period, and a serious condition
results that takes some time to rectify, the landlord should be responsible for
the tenants’ loss of use of their unit or the common facilities during the
repairs.  However, if the landlord has a reasonable program of maintenance,
including preventative maintenance, and is acting responsibly to rectify a
problem that requires extensive repairs, an abatement of rent should not be
ordered.
46.  The Tenant’s Agent relied upon an
earlier decision of the Landlord and Tenant Board (the ‘Board’), CET-29301-14,
issued on March 26, 2013.  While past decisions of the Board are not binding on
me, it is worth noting that this order predates Onyskiw.  In
CET-29301-13, the Member relied upon the now outdated contractual analysis of Offredi
v. 751768 Ontario Ltd.[7] 
As a result, I find that this case is of no assistance.
47.  Following the analysis in Onyskiw, I find
that since the Landlord demonstrated a proactive program of maintenance and
acted responsibly and in a very timely manner to resolve the Tenant’s concerns
and was obstructed by the unreasonable actions of the Tenant’s boyfriend, it
was not in breach of its responsibilities under subsection 20(1) of the Act
with respect to the water heater.
Other Issues
48.  The tenancy agreement was signed by the Tenant and A.A. on
July 20, 2017.  On the second page of the contract, the parties agreed to the
following additional conditions:
Landlord
agrees to supply the following:
Screens
(2)
More
Cupboards and Counter top for the kitchen.
1
window already ordered for the rear bedroom.
Storm
door (longer)
49.  Both the Tenant and A.A. signed below this addendum.  The
Tenant acknowledged that the Landlord has replaced one double pane window.
50.  However, none of these issues, or another problem with a
door, were mentioned in either application.  As a result, the Tenant failed to
provide the Landlord with reasonable notice that she intended to raise these
issues at the hearing.  Consequently, these issues will form no part of the order
to follow.
51.  This order contains all of the reasons in this matter and
no further reasons will issue.
It is ordered that:
The L1 and the T6 Applications

 
1.     
Unless the Tenant voids the
order as set out below, the tenancy between the Landlord and the Tenant is
terminated.  The Tenant must move out of the rental unit on or before June 30,
2018.
2.     
The Tenant shall pay to the
Landlord $1,897.87*, which represents the amount of rent owing and compensation
up to June 8, 2018, less the rent deposit and interest the Landlord owes on the
rent deposit and less the amount of the abatement the Landlord owes the Tenant.
3.     
The Tenant shall also pay to
the Landlord $34.52 per day for compensation for the use of the unit starting
June 9, 2018 to the date the Tenant moves out of the unit.
4.     
The Tenant shall also pay to
the Landlord $175.00 for the cost of filing the application.
5.     
If the Tenant does not pay
the Landlord the full amount owing* on or before June 30, 2018, the Tenant will
start to owe interest.  This will be simple interest calculated from July 1,
2018 at 3.00% annually on the balance outstanding.
6.     
If the unit is not vacated
on or before June 30, 2018, then starting July 1, 2018, the Landlord may file
this order with the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may
be enforced.
7.     
Upon receipt of this order,
the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) is directed to give vacant possession of
the unit to the Landlord, on or after July 1, 2018.
8.     
If, on or before June 30,
2018, the Tenant pays the amount of $3,965.23** to the Landlord or to the Board
in trust, this order for eviction will be void.  This means that the tenancy
would not be terminated and the Tenant could remain in the unit.  If this
payment is not made in full and on time, the Landlord may file this order with
the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) so that the eviction may be enforced.
9.     
The Tenant may make a motion
to the Board under subsection 74(11) of the Act to set aside this order if she
pays the amount required under that subsection on or after July 1, 2018, but
before the Sheriff gives vacant possession to the Landlord.  The Tenant is only
entitled to make this motion once during the period of the tenancy agreement
with the Landlord.
The T2 Application
10.  The Tenant’s application is dismissed.
 
June 8, 2018                                                                     _______________________
Date Issued                                                                      Kevin
Lundy
                                                                                                                           Member,
Landlord and Tenant Board
 
South West-RO
150 Dufferin Avenue,
Suite 400, 4th Floor
London ON N6A5N6
 
If you have any
questions about this order, call 416-645-8080 or toll free at 1-888-332-3234.
 
In accordance with
section 81 of the Act, the part of this order relating to the eviction expires
on January 1, 2019 if the order has not been filed on or before this date with
the Court Enforcement Office (Sheriff) that has territorial jurisdiction where
the rental unit is located.

**         Refer to
